title: How to Make Buckwheat Cakes

steps.headline: Start the night before by combining the warm milk, yeast, honey, and buckwheat flour in large, non-reactive bowl (pottery works best).
Mix well, cover with a clean kitchen towel and leave in warm place overnight.
steps.description: You may want to place the bowl on a cookie sheet because if your starter is especially active, it could overflow the bowl.

steps.headline: Continue the next day by adding the rest of the ingredients.
steps.description: You want to add only enough water to make a very thin batter (anywhere from 1/2 to 1 cup); what you are looking for is the consistency of a crepe batter.

steps.headline: Reserve 1 cup of the batter for starter for future cakes; refrigerate in a covered jar.

text: Start the night before by combining the warm milk, yeast, honey, and buckwheat flour in large, non-reactive bowl (pottery works best).  Mix well, cover with a clean kitchen towel and leave in warm place overnight. You may want to place the bowl on a cookie sheet because if your starter is especially active, it could overflow the bowl. Continue the next day by adding the rest of the ingredients. You want to add only enough water to make a very thin batter (anywhere from 1/2 to 1 cup); what you are looking for is the consistency of a crepe batter. Reserve 1 cup of the batter for starter for future cakes; refrigerate in a covered jar.  Pour ladle of batter onto a hot, well-seasoned griddle; as soon as you pour, take the bottom of the ladle and spread the batter into a thin circle. If done properly, the cakes should very quickly form tiny holes on the surface. Turn once the top is dry. Finished.
